abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Labor Market
            Development Project (LMDP) were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Several lessons have been learned from
            this pilot project in both policy and operational
            perspectives. A broader set of lessons are: first, putting
            in place a rational and enabling labor market policy
            framework is key to reducing labor market rigidity and
            segregation and increasing labor mobility and employment
            flexibility; second, when an economy continues to grow
            rapidly and jobs are being created, active labor market
            policies, especially employment services and training
            including retraining could have a positive impact on
            employment and reemployment if they were well targeted and
            integrated; third, information is essential to help equip
            workers in transition between jobs and to seize
            opportunities to acquire new skills; and fourth, the
            trainability and employability of workers depend largely on
            their education background. More specific lessons learned
            are: (1) building a bridge between the labor market, service
            providers, job seekers, and employers can be facilitated by
            a LMDP; (2) the experience of implementation of employment
            services and in-service training, has proven that such
            integration contributes to higher placement/employment rate
            and increased relevance and effectiveness of the training
            provided; (3) the LMDP experience suggests that a complex
            pilot project that depends upon the effective implementation
            of policy and legal reforms to achieve its objectives
            requires the involvement of all key stakeholders at the
            outset of its preparation and design to ensure their
            commitment to, and perseverance in, successfully completing
            the execution of all project activities; (4) effective
            institutional development through technology transfer can be
            realized when a foreign firm and a local enterprise are able
            to work collaboratively to achieve an agreed objective
            within a given timeframe; (5) the LMDP has reinforced the
            principle that project implementation success and the
            sustainability of its investments in legal and policy
            reforms depend crucially upon the integration of systematic
            staff training and its timing with key activities relating
            to those reforms; and (6) the successful implementation of a
            project involving complex policy and legal reforms aimed at
            changing the structure of a key sector of the economy is
            best assured when the objectives are in line with the
            borrower's sector policies and the implementation
            timing and strategies harmonize with the government's
            readiness for change to quicken economic and social development.
